Title: Ipsilateral connections of the anterior cingulate cortex with the frontal and medial temporal cortices in the macaque
Abstract:
The present study was attempted to study ipsilateral corticocortical connections of the anterior part (area 24) of the cingulate cortex of the macaque monkey by means of wheat germ agglutinin-conjugated peroxidase (WGA-HRP) method. In 2 out of 4 Japanese monkeys (Macaca fuscata) that were injected with WGA-HRP into the anterior part of the cingulate cortex, the sites of injection were successfully localized within the cortical regions corresponding to areas 24a and 24b. The results obtained from these monkeys indicate that areas 24a and 24b in the anterior part of the cingulate cortex are reciprocally connected with the prefrontal, premotor, and motor cortical
regions, and also with the medial temporal cortical regions. Areas 24a and 24b were strongly connected with the lateral and medial
prefrontal cortices and area 6a beta of the premotor cortex, moderately with the remaining premotor cortex, and weakly with the motor cortex. In the medial temporal cortex, areas 24a and 24b were strongly connected with the prosubiculum, entorhinal cortex (area 28), and perirhinal cortex (areas 35 and 36), and weakly with areas TF and TH of the parahippocampal gyrus, throughout their rostrocaudal extent. In addition, areas 24a and 24b projected to the molecular layer of the CAI subfield of Ammon's horn and the external pyramidal layer of the presubiculum. Our findings suggest that areas 24a and 24b of the anterior cingulate cortex may constitute relays in the
reciprocal pathways between the prefrontal cortex and the hippocampal, entorhinal and/or perirhinal cortical regions.

@BrainMaps_Delineation.Citation: "Wga-HRP was injected into cytoarchitectonically defined regions of area 24 on the medial surface of the anterior cingulate cortex. Therefore, a brief description of cytoarcvhitecture and borders of subdivisions of area 24 in the brain of the Japanese macaque is appropriate here. Area 24, which lacks layer IV, is located in the anterior portion of the cingulate cortex in the macaque monkey, and it is cytoarchitecturally subdivided into areas 24a, 24b, 24c, and 24d (Matelli et al., 1991). Area 24a shows the fusion of layers V and VI and occupies the lower part of the medial surface of the anterior cingulate cortex. In area 24b, layer V is clearly separated from layer VI. Area 24b lies above area 24a and extends over the medial part of the ventral bank of the cingulate sulcus. Areas 24c and 24d have a broad layer III and occupy the depth of the ventral and dorsal banks and fundus of the cingulate sulcus. Area 24c is located rostrally to area 24d and is richer in large cells in layer V than area 24d. The border between areas 24c and 24d corresponds approximately to the level at which area 6a-alpha is replaced by area 6a-beta. Area 24d continues caudally to area 23 at the level at which area 6a-alpha changes to area 4a. Area 32 that was divided by Pandya et al. (1981) is located immediately rostral to area 24 and has a poorly developed layer IV and undifferentiated layers V and VI." (p. 21)

@BrainMaps_UnspecificAdoption.Citation: "Cortical designations of the brain of the Macaque monkey were based on the work of Brodmann (1925), Vogt and Vogt (1919), and Walker (1940). Cytoarchitectural subdivisions of area 24 were those referred to in the works of Vogt et al. (1987) and Matelli et al. (1991). Borders of the perirhinal cortex and prosubiculum were based on studies by Amaral et al. (1987) and Lorente de Nó (1934), respectively." (p. 21)

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "HRP-labeled cells and terminals were distributed in the ipsilateral entorhinal cortex ( area 28 of Brodmann ) at rostrocaudal levels from the beginning of the rhinal sulcus to its disappearance. ..... No labeled cells or terminals were found in the olfactory field of the entorhinal cortex, which lies in the medial part of area 28 ventral to the amygdala ( Amaral etr al., 1987 )
"The motor cortex is subdivided cytoarchitecurally into areas 4a, 4b, nd 4c (Vogt and Vogt, 1919)." (p. 23)
"Cortical designations of the brain of the Macaque monkey were based on the work of Brodmann (1925), Vogt and Vogt (1919), and Walker (1940)." (p. 21)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: The text does not unambiguously state what map area 10 is taken from. However, it seems likely that it is defined according to Walker 1940 because (i) W40 is a standard parcellation scheme for the prefrontal region, whereas Brodmann's and Vogt's maps are seldom used for this region, and (ii) Fig. 2 shows a labelled area 10 in a position that is compatible with Walker's area 10.

"Area 24, which lacks layer IV, is located in the anterior portion of the cingulate cortex in the Macaque monkey, and it is cytoarchitecturally subdivided into areas 24a, 24b, 24c, and 24d (Matelli et al. 1991)." (p. 21)

@Injections.Citation: "The center of injection site was located in the rostral portion of area 24 of the anterior cingulate cortex at the level behind the genu of the corpus callosum on the right hemisphere, and the injection site extended about 4mm rostrocaudally. The injection was confined to areas 24a and 24b on the medial surface of the anterior cingulate cortex (Fig. 1A)."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: " Area 24a and 24b of the anterior cingulate cortex were strongly interconnected with the rostral regions of the lateral and medial prefrontal cortices and area 6a-beta of the premotor cortex, moderately with the remaining regions of the premotor cortex, and weakly with the motor cortex (Fig. 2)."  (pp. 21, 23)
@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Comments:
In contrast to labeled somata, which are shown by the figures, there are no figures showing labeled terminals: "Since HRP-labeled cells and terminals were colocalized everywhere in the cortex, apart from the presubiculum, only HRP-labeled cells were plotted as dots on the outlines of the brain." (p. 21)
As a general rule, we thus interpreted cortical regions that are mentioned by the text to be "labeled" to contain both labeled cells and terminals. If for a particular area only "labeled cells" were explcitly mentioned, however, we refrained from assuming the co-existence of labeled terminals for this area.

If for a particular area only "labeled cells" were explcitly mentioned, however, we refrained from assuming the co-existence of labeled terminals for this area.

@Injections.Citation: "The center of the injection site was located in the caudal portion of the anterior cingulate cortex at the level of the anterior commissure, and the injection site extended about 8mm rostrocaudally. The injection site involved areas 24a and 24b on the medial surface of the caudal part of the anterior cingulate cortex and encroached on the infragranular layers of part of area 24d on the ventral bank of the cingulate sulcus. There was slight damage to tissue in area 24a at the site of the pipette tip, and there was diffusion of the tracer into the cingulum bundle and callosal fibers."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: " In case 900803, the injection site involved not only caudal areas 24a and 24b at the level of the anterior  commissure, but also area 24d, the cingulum bundle, and the corpus callosum. Hence, connections observed in this case might include connections between the frontal cortex and area 24d, the posterior cingulate cortex, the retrosplenial cortex, or the contralateral frontal cortex, in addition to the connection between the frontal cortex and areas 24a and 24b. Since the injection site of this case included the caudal area 24a and 24b, we will briefly describe the results of this case for comparison purpose." (p. 33 )

@Injections.Citation: "The injection site was centered in the rostral portion of area 24 on the left hemisphere at the level of the rostral pole of the putamen, extending about 4mm rostrocaudally. It was located more caudally than in case 900517 and involved areas 24a and 24b. It encroached on the infragranular layers of area 24c on the ventral bank of the cingulate sulcus."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "In case 901113, the injection site was not confined to areas 24a and 24b at the level of the genu of corpus callosum, and included a part of area 24c on the ventral bank of the cingulate sulcus, the cingulum bundle, and a part of the corpus callosum. It is possible that labeling was the result of uptake of HRP not only from rostral areas 24a and 24b, but also from the rostral area 24c, the cingulum bundle fibers that pass from the prefrontal cortex to the posterior cingulate cortex or vice versa, or from the callosal fibers that innervate the contralateral  frontal cortex. In fact, labeled cells and terminals in case 901113 were distributed more densely and broadly in the frontal and medial temporal cortices than those in case 900517." (pp. 27, 29)

@Injections.Citation: "The injection site was small and localized within area 24a and 24b of the anterior cingulate cortex at the level of the genu of the corpus callosum on the right hemisphere. It was located a little more caudally than that in case 900517."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation:
" In cases 900517 and 910226, the injection sites were localized within areas 24a and 24b in the rostral part of the anterior cingulate cortex and in both cases the patterns of cortical and laminar distribution of HRP labeled cells and terminals were similar. publication.title: Ipsilateral connections of the anterior cingulate cortex with the frontal and medial temporal cortices in the macaque
publication.abstract:
The present study was attempted to study ipsilateral corticocortical connections of the anterior part (area 24) of the cingulate cortex of the macaque monkey by means of wheat germ agglutinin-conjugated peroxidase (WGA-HRP) method. In 2 out of 4 Japanese monkeys (Macaca fuscata) that were injected with WGA-HRP into the anterior part of the cingulate cortex, the sites of injection were successfully localized within the cortical regions corresponding to areas 24a and 24b. The results obtained from these monkeys indicate that areas 24a and 24b in the anterior part of the cingulate cortex are reciprocally connected with the prefrontal, premotor, and motor cortical
regions, and also with the medial temporal cortical regions. Areas 24a and 24b were strongly connected with the lateral and medial
prefrontal cortices and area 6a beta of the premotor cortex, moderately with the remaining premotor cortex, and weakly with the motor cortex. In the medial temporal cortex, areas 24a and 24b were strongly connected with the prosubiculum, entorhinal cortex (area 28), and perirhinal cortex (areas 35 and 36), and weakly with areas TF and TH of the parahippocampal gyrus, throughout their rostrocaudal extent. In addition, areas 24a and 24b projected to the molecular layer of the CAI subfield of Ammon's horn and the external pyramidal layer of the presubiculum. Our findings suggest that areas 24a and 24b of the anterior cingulate cortex may constitute relays in the
reciprocal pathways between the prefrontal cortex and the hippocampal, entorhinal and/or perirhinal cortical regions.
